questions.text: 1. A lethargic infant was presented with vomiting and irritability. He was diagnosed with an X-linked recessive disorder due to the deficiency of ornithine transcarbamoylase. What is the likely disorder?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with a deficiency in enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase is likely to have a diagnosis of type 2 hyperammonemia inherited in an X-linked recessive manner.

In the urea cycle, the enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase catalyzes the condensation of carbamoyl phosphate with ornithine to form citrulline. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate leading to elevated levels of glutamine in the blood, urine, and cerebrospinal fluid. 

Infants present with vomiting, irritability, lethargy, hypothermia, and apnea due to high ammonia levels in the plasma. Mothers also have an aversion to protein-rich foods. 

Urea cycle disorders are all characterized by hyperammonemia, encephalopathy, and respiratory alkalosis. This is due to an accumulation of the precursors of urea namely ammonia, and glutamine.

The enzymes involved in the urea cycle with their related disorders are given below:

* Carbamoyl-phosphate synthetase (CPS) 1 deficiency (hyperammonemia type 1) - rare and characterized by severe hyperammonemia.

* Ornithine transporter deficiency (HHH syndrome) - is characterized by hyperornithinemia, hyperammonemia, and homocitrullinuria.

* Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency (hyperammonemia type 2) - is inherited as an X-linked trait. Characterized by hyperammonemia and elevated glutamine levels in blood and CSF.

* Argininosuccinate synthetase deficiency - is characterized by increased citrulline, citrullinuria, and hyperammonemia.

* Argininosuccinate lyase deficiency- leads to argininosuccinic acidemia and metabolic acidosis. Hyperammonemia is less severe and argininosuccinate is found in urine and CSF.

* Arginase deficiency- mild variety. Characterized by hyperargininemia and argininuria.

Clinical features of urea cycle disorders are common to all and include vomiting, avoidance of high-protein foods, intermittent ataxia, irritability, lethargy, and severe mental retardation. 

Long terms treatment consists of a protein-restricted diet.

Pearl PM0573: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: 2. A child who presents with hypotonia and seizures is diagnosed with Zellweger syndrome. All of the following findings are seen in this patient except?

choices.text: Mutation in PEX family of genes

questions.solution:
Zellweger syndrome is associated with a marked reduction of plasmalogens.

Zellweger syndrome or cerebrohepatorenal syndrome is due to defective biogenesis of peroxisomes. Mutations in the PEX (Option D) family of genes are implicated leading to a defective transport of proteins from the cytosol to the peroxisomes. This affects the metabolic pathways which are exclusive to the peroxisome such as 

* β oxidation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA) is affected leading to the accumulation of VLCFA. (Option B)

* α oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids (such as phytanic acid) leading to accumulation of phytanic acid.

* Synthesis of bile acids is affected (Option C) 

* Synthesis of plasmalogens is affected causing a marked reduction in plasmalogen levels. (Option A) 

The child presents with dysmorphic facial features like large anterior fontanelles, hypoplastic supraorbital ridges, micrognathia, and redundant nuchal skin folds. Profound developmental delay, hypotonia with depressed deep tendon reflexes, neonatal seizures, and impaired hearing are seen. Other observed abnormalities are calcific stippling of the epiphysis, renal cysts, and liver cirrhosis. There is no appropriate treatment for Zellweger syndrome. It is very severe and infants rarely survive beyond six months of age.

Other diseases of peroxisome are:

Refsum's disease results from the defect in alpha oxidation of fatty acids such as phytanic acid in the peroxisome leading to elevated levels of phytanic acid in the blood. VLCFA levels are normal in this condition.

In X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy, the defect is an inability to transport VLCFA into the peroxisome, but other peroxisomal functions, such as α-oxidation, are normal. Elevated levels of VLCFA are seen in all tissues with normal phytanic acid levels.

Pearl PM0729: Types, Location and Properties of Fatty acid oxidation

Types of Oxidation

Location

Properties

Associated Disease

Beta oxidation

Mitochondria

A catabolic process by which two-carbons are cleaved from the fatty acid molecule and released as acetyl CoA starting from the carboxyl end.

The chain is broken between the α(2) and β(3) carbon.

1 round of beta-oxidation yield 1FADH2, 1NADH, and 1 Acetyl CoA.

  

Alpha oxidation

Peroxisome

The presence of the 3-methyl group of phytanic acid prevents degradation by beta-oxidation.

The chain is broken between the terminal carboxyl group and α(2) carbon removing that carbon as CO2. The remaining chain is activated with CoA and then undergoes β-Oxidation.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Classic Refsum's Disease

Defective enzyme- Phytanoyl Coa hydroxylase.

Clinical features include:

Ichthyosis, Retinitis pigmentosa, Decreased vision, Peripheral neuropathy, Ataxia

 

Omega oxidation

Endoplasmic Reticulum

An alternative pathway to beta-oxidation occurs in microsomes.

Involves the oxidation of the ω carbon (terminal methyl group) resulting in dicarboxylic acid.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

  

Peroxisomal Beta oxidation

Peroxisome

Very-long-chain fatty acids undergo preliminary β-oxidation in peroxisomes up to octanoyl CoA. The shortened fatty acids undergo further β-oxidation in the mitochondria.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome

A rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues.

They accumulate C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. The disease causes severe neurologic symptoms, and most patients die in the first year of life.

questions.text:
3. Which of the following are vitamin B12-dependent enzymes?

1. Methyl malonyl CoA mutase 2. Homocysteine synthase 3. Folate reductase 4. Methionine synthase
questions.solution:
Among the given enzymes, 1 and 4 i.e., methyl malonyl CoA mutase and methionine synthase are vitamin B12-dependent enzymes. 

Vitamin B12 or cobalamin is a water-soluble vitamin that is derived from animal products such as red meat, dairy, and eggs. Its absorption in the terminal ileum is facilitated by the presence of intrinsic factor, produced by parietal cells in the stomach. There are two vitamin B12-dependent enzymes:

* Methionine synthase (homocysteine methyltransferase) - catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine

* Methylmalonyl CoA mutase - methylmalonyl CoA, formed as an intermediate in the catabolism of valine, isoleucine, and propionyl CoA is converted to succinyl CoA

The image below shows B12 serving as a cofactor of methionine synthase.



The conversion of 5,10-methylene-THF into 5-methyl-THF (methyltetrahydrofolate) is an irreversible process. The major source of tetrahydrofolate for tissues is 5-methyl-THF. The only way to make further use of 5-methyl-THF and to maintain the folate cycle is by the vitamin B12-dependent remethylation of homocysteine to methionine by the methioninesynthase enzyme.

Decreased activity of methionine synthase in vitamin B12 deficiency results in the accumulation of methyltetrahydrofolate, which cannot be used, resulting in a folate trap. The folate cycle acts as the link between the functions of folate and vitamin B12, and a deficiency of vitamin B12 can cause a functional deficiency of folate.

The activity of methylmalonyl CoA mutase is greatly reduced in vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to an accumulation of methylmalonic acid and its excretion in urine. Since vitamin B12 is also linked to the regeneration of methionine from homocysteine, its deficiency can result in hyperhomocysteinemia as well.

Urinary excretion of methylmalonic acid is also used to differentiate between megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text: 4. Which of the following is an example of anaplerotic reaction?
questions.solution:
Carboxylation of pyruvate to oxaloacetate is an example of anaplerotic reaction.

Anaplerotic reactions are chemical reactions that form intermediates of a metabolic pathway. It is an act of replenishing TCA cycle intermediates that have been extracted for biosynthesis.

Examples include:

* Carboxylation of pyruvate to oxaloacetate

* Transamination of aspartate to oxaloacetate by aspartate amino transferase

* Hydration of glutamate to alpha-ketoglutarate-dehydrogenase

* Beta oxidation of fatty acid to succinnyl–CoA

* In purine synthesis and purine nucleotide cycle: Adenylosuccinate to fumarate catalysed by adenylosuccinate lyase.

questions.text: 5. An infant demonstrates lethargy, vomiting, and convulsions after a few sessions of breastfeeding. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of ammonia. It is found that the infant has a defect in an enzyme activated by N-acetyl glutamate. Identify the enzyme.
questions.solution:
N-acetyl glutamate is an allosteric activator of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS I). CPS I catalyzes the rate-limiting step in the urea cycle and is present in the mitochondria. This reaction uses up two molecules of ATP to generate one molecule of carbamoyl phosphate. Its defect leads to hyperammonemia type 1.

The clinical symptoms of urea cycle disorders include vomiting, intermittent ataxia, irritability, lethargy, severe mental retardation, hypothermia, and apnea due to high plasma ammonia levels.

Option A: Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II is the rate-limiting enzyme in pyrimidine synthesis. It is inhibited by UTP (uridine triphosphate) and activated by ATP and PRPP (phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate).

CPS I  CPS II
Rate-limiting enzyme of urea cycle Rate limiting step of pyrimidine synthesis
Found in mitochondria Found in cytosol
Uses ammonia as a source of nitrogen Uses glutamine as a source of nitrogen
Requires N-acetyl glutamate as a positive allosteric activator Does not require N-acetyl glutamate


Option C: Ornithine transcarbamoylase combines carbamoyl phosphate with ornithine to form citrulline. Deficiency causes elevated glutamine levels in the blood, CSF, and urine.

Option D: Argininosuccinate synthetase leads to the synthesis of argininosuccinate from citrulline and aspartate.

Pearl PM0573: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: 6. Which step/moiety involved in the process of beta-oxidation of fatty acid is affected by sulfonylureas used to control hyperglycaemia?
questions.solution:
The sulfonylurea drugs (glyburide, glibenclamide and tolbutamide), used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus, reduce fatty acid oxidation. Therefore, it controls hyperglycemia by inhibiting carnitine palmitoyl transferase - I (CPT-I). 

The pearls attached below summarize the steps involved in the beta-oxidation of fatty acids.

Pearl PM0637: Beta-oxidation of Fatty Acids



Note: Carnitine palmitoyltransferase I (CPT1) is also known as carnitine acyltransferase I,

questions.text: 7. The image given below depicts the steps in glycogenolysis. Match the enzymes involved correctly.

choices.text: A - Phosphorylase, B - Glucan transferase, C - Debranching enzyme
A - Debranching enzyme, B - Phosphorylase, C - Glucan Transferase
A - Glucan Transferase, B - Phosphorylase, C - Debranching enzyme
A – Debranching enzyme, B – Glucan transferase, C - Phosphorylase

questions.solution:
A - Phosphorylase, B - Glucan transferase, C - Debranching enzyme.

Steps of glycogenolysis:

* Step 1: There is breaking of alpha 1,4 linkages in glycogen by glycogen phosphorylase (rate limiting step)

* Step 2: There is transfer of trisaccharide residue from one branch to another by glucan transferase, forming new alpha 1, 4 bond. Thus the alpha 1,6 branch point from where the residue is transferred, is exposed.

* Step 3: Alpha 1,6 glucosidase hydrolyses this exposed branching point, leading to glucose 1 phosphate.

* Step 4: Glucose 1 phosphate is converted to glucose 6 phosphate by phosphoglucomutase.

* Step 5: In liver, phosphatase converts glucose 6 phosphate to glucose.



Pearl PM0963: Glycogenolysis

questions.text: 8. A young man with chronic bacterial prostatitis was treated with cotrimoxazole. During treatment, he developed malaise, jaundice, abdominal pain, and dark urine. Findings of a peripheral smear are shown below. The defect in which of the following pathways leads to the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario and peripheral smear showing bite cells is suggestive of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, the enzyme which is involved in the hexose monophosphate (HMP) pathway. 

The clinical features are suggestive of an acute hemolytic reaction following the administration of cotrimoxazole. A hemolytic attack starts with abrupt onset of malaise, weakness, and abdominal or lumbar pain. After an interval of several hours to 2–3 days, the patient develops jaundice and often dark urine, due to hemoglobinuria. 

G6PD is an enzyme that plays a critical role in redox reactions that occur in all aerobic cells. It is the only source of NADPH in erythrocytes that helps in the formation of reduced glutathione. This reduced form protects erythrocytes against oxidative stress.

G6PD deficiency is an X-linked inheritance disorder. Most patients with this condition are asymptomatic. But when exposed to oxidative triggers, they are prone to develop acute hemolytic anemia. The various oxidative triggers include:

* Fava beans

* Infections

* Drugs such as primaquine, chloroquine, sulfonamides/sulfones, dapsone, and nitrofurantoin

Cotrimoxazole contains sulfamethoxazole which triggers a hemolytic reaction in persons with G6PD deficiency. The peripheral smear shows characteristic "bite cells" or degmacytes or blister cells. In G6PD deficiency, uncontrolled oxidative stress causes hemoglobin to denature and form Heinz bodies. Bite cells result from the removal of Heinz bodies by macrophages in the spleen.

questions.text: 9. An infant with abdominal distension, fever, and jaundice was brought to the pediatric OPD. On further evaluation, a diagnosis of an autosomal recessive disorder due to a defect in the enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase was arrived at. What is the likely disorder?
questions.solution:
The autosomal recessive disorder due to a defect in the enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase in a child with abdominal distension, fever and jaundice is associated with Hepatorenal tyrosinemia (Type 1 tyrosinemia or tyrosinosis). It is the most common type of tyrosinemia. 

There are three types of tyrosinemias:

* Type 1 (Hepatorenal tyrosinemia):

* Defective enzyme: Fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase 

* Inherited as an autosomal recessive trait

* Clinical features: Liver failure, hypoglycemia, boiled cabbage odour in the urine, and mental retardation. 

* Type 2 (Oculocutaneous tyrosinemia/Richner-Hanhart syndrome):

* Defective enzyme: Tyrosine transaminase 

* Clinical features: Palmoplantar keratosis, painful corneal erosions, photophobia, mental retardation are seen. 

* Type 3 (Neonatal tyrosinemia): 

* Defective enzyme: 4-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase 

* Clinical features: Normal liver function, developmental delay, seizures and intermittent ataxia are seen.

* Hawkinsuria

* Defective enzyme: 4-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase 

* Inherited as an autosomal dominant trait

* Clinical features: Transient failure to thrive and metabolic acidosis in infancy

questions.text: 10. A patient diagnosed with primary hyperoxaluria is most likely to have a deficiency of which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
A patient diagnosed with primary hyperoxaluria is most likely to have a glycine deficiency.

Primary hyperoxalurias are a group of inborn errors of metabolism characterized by oxalate overproduction, with an autosomal recessive inheritance. There are 3 types of primary hyperoxalurias, of which primary hyperoxaluria type 1 (PH1) is the most common form.

The defect in PH1 is the deficiency of the alanine-glyoxylate aminotransferase in liver peroxisomes. This causes failure to catabolize glyoxylate to glycine. Glyoxylate is instead converted to oxalate, with consequent calcium oxalate stone formation and crystal deposition in various organs like the kidney. 

Age at onset of symptoms ranges from infancy to the sixth decade, with the median age being 4–6 years. Presenting symptoms include hematuria, dysuria, pain, urinary tract infection, or stone passage. In severe, early-onset disease, there is nephrocalcinosis with or without nephrolithiasis and failure to thrive related to renal failure.

A urinalysis shows elevated urinary oxalate and elevated urinary glycolic acid. There is also an elevated level of plasma oxalate. Renal ultrasound may show multiple bilateral radiopaque calculi.

The FDA recently approved lumasiran, an RNA interference therapeutic agent targeting glycolate oxidase, as the first treatment option for PH1, a rare genetic disorder.

questions.text:
11. A 4-year-old child with normal developmental milestones presents with diurnal variations of insomnia, dystonia of lower limbs, and toe gait. She is unable to write and she has associated torticollis. Lab levels revealed normal serotonin and phenylalanine levels. A diagnosis was later confirmed as Segawa syndrome. The compound deficient in this condition acts as a co-factor for:

* Phenylalanine hydroxylase

* Tyrosine hydroxylase

* Nitric oxide synthase

* Tryptophan hydroxylase

* GTP cyclohydrolase
questions.solution:
Segawa syndrome (Dopamine-responsive dystonia) is a hereditary, autosomal dominant progressive dystonia due to the deficiency of tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4). BH4 serves as a cofactor for enzymes 1, 2, 3, and 4.

The condition is due to the defective GTP cyclohydrolase I enzyme required for BH4 synthesis(Statement 5).

BH4 deficiency leads to a defect in the cofactor for tyrosine hydroxylase, leading to impairment in the production of DOPA and dopamine. Hence, it is characterized by increased muscle tone and parkinsonian features, typically absent in the morning or after rest but worsening during the day and with exertion.

The clinical spectrum includes tremors, toe gait, and dystonia specifically of the lower limbs. The late presentation includes writer's cramps, torticollis, and postural dystonia. It may be associated with serotonin deficiency - sleep disturbance, cognitive impairment, and impulsivity.

Lab Findings:

* Normal phenylalanine levels but phenylalanine loading test (100mg/kg) causes increase in phenylalanine levels with increased phenylalanine: tyrosine ratio. This ratio (measured after 2-3 hrs of the load) along with urine neopterin has high specificity and sensitivity.

* Confirmation is by CSF assay for BH4 and Neopterin which are significantly low

Treatment: Segawa syndrome responds well to levodopa. Oral BH4 can be useful but is rarely used.

Other disorders with normal phenylalanine levels:

* Aromatic amino acid decarboxylase deficiencies

* Dopamine Beta hydroxylase deficiency

* Monoamine oxidase enzyme deficiency

* GABA transaminase deficiency

* Gamma Hydroxybutyric aciduria - Succinic Semialdehyde Dehydrogenase Deficiency

* Dopamine Transporter (DAT) defects

* Non-classical Phenylketonuria (PKU)

Phenylketonuria (PKU) is the most common inborn error of amino acid metabolism, primarily due to a defect in phenylalanine hydroxylase (classic PKU) or, less commonly, dihydropteridine reductase (non-classical PKU). Both lead to impaired phenylalanine-to-tyrosine conversion.

Classical PKU has elevated levels of phenylalanine metabolites and decreased levels of tyrosine, which gives rise to typical clinical features (Intellectual disability, light skin color, blue eyes).

Non-classical PKU, caused by dihydro pteridine reductase deficiency, results in normal phenylalanine levels but decreased catecholamines and 5-hydroxytryptophan due to impaired tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) synthesis.

Pearl PM2196: Amino Acid Derivatives

questions.text:

Column A Column B
1. Type I a. Defective LDL receptors
2. Type IIa b. Overproduction of VLDL
3. Type III c. Hepatic lipase deficiency
4. Type IV d. Defective apo E

questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-e, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b.

2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and tendon xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL  Atherosclerosis, palmar and tuberoeruptive xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: 13. A known case of type 1 diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency room with severe nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. She has a fruity odor of breath and is hyperglycemic. Which of the following is the rate-limiting enzyme for the product responsible for the given positive test?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with the image showing positive Rothera's test is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis. The positive Rothera's test is given by ketone bodies and the rate-limiting enzyme in ketone bodies synthesis is mitochondrial HMG CoA synthase.

Type I diabetes mellitus is a low insulin state. There is an increased conversion of fatty acids to acetyl-CoA which in turn leads to increased ketone body production. The presence of ketosis can be established by the detection of ketone bodies in urine by Rothera's test.

The ketone bodies synthesized in the liver mitochondria are transported in the blood to the peripheral tissues, where they are utilized by the following steps:

* β-hydroxybutyrate is oxidized to acetoacetate by β-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase producing NADH.

* Acetoacetate is then activated to acetoacetyl CoA by transferring a CoA molecule from succinyl CoA by succinyl CoA-acetoacetate CoA transferase (thiophorase).

* Acetoacetyl CoA is cleaved into two acetyl CoA molecules by thiolase and oxidized into CO2 by the TCA cycle.

Ketone bodies are utilized by extrahepatic tissue like the cardiac muscle and renal cortex (prefer the ketone bodies to glucose as fuel). Tissues like skeletal muscle and the brain can also utilize the ketone bodies as alternate sources of energy if glucose is not available.

RBCs cannot utilize ketone bodies as they lack mitochondria. The liver cannot utilize ketone bodies as it lacks the enzyme thiophorase.

Rothera's test:

* Saturate 5 mL of urine with solid ammonium sulfate.

* Add 3 drops of freshly prepared sodium nitroprusside

* Add 2 mL of liquor ammonia along the sides of the test tube.

The development of a purple ring at the junction of the two liquids (shown in the image below) indicates the presence of acetone or acetoacetic acid in urine. It is not answered by beta-hydroxybutyrate.



Other options

Option A: HMG CoA lyase is involved in ketone body synthesis

Option B: HMG CoA reductase is the rate-limiting enzyme in the synthesis of cholesterol.

Option D: Cytoplasmic HMG CoA synthase is involved in cholesterol synthesis.

Pearl PM0735: Ketone body utilisation



1. 3-Hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase

2. CoA Transferase

3. Thiolase

questions.text: 14. A 6-month-old baby was brought to the clinic with failure to thrive. On examination, generalized hypotonia and hepatomegaly were present. A chest X-ray image shows massive cardiomegaly. Microscopy of a muscle biopsy shows vacuolations. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Type II (Pompe's disease) glycogen storage disease is the most probable diagnosis from the above-given clinical scenario.

The clinical symptoms are hypotonia (floppy infant), hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and chest X-ray image shows cardiomegaly, which is characteristically seen in Pompe's disease. The muscle biopsy showing vacuoles further aids the diagnosis. 

Pompe disease (glycogen storage disease type II) is due to the deficiency of the enzyme lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase. The affected child usually dies around the age of 2 years due to heart failure.

The enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) for Pompe disease is the recombinant enzyme a-glucosidase alfa (Myozyme).

questions.text: 15. A 12-year-old child presented with fatigue, growth retardation, and neurologic abnormalities. Peripheral blood smear revealed megaloblastic anaemia. The condition did not improve with administration of vitamin B12 and folate, but responded to treatment with uridine. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Megaloblastic anaemia that is responsive to uridine is consistent with orotic aciduria.

Orotic aciduria is a rare inborn error of metabolism in children. A defect in the enzyme uridine-5′-monophosphate (UMP) synthase in the pyrimidine synthesis pathway results in the failure of conversion of orotic acid to uridine. As a result, there is increased excretion of orotic acid in urine.

The condition is characterized by hypochromic megaloblastic anaemia that is unresponsive to vitamin B12 and folic acid, growth retardation, and neurologic abnormalities.

Treatment includes administration of uridine (100–200 mg/kg per day), which corrects anaemia, reduces orotic acid excretion and improves the other sequelae of the disorder.

Causes of megaloblastic anaemia:-

* Cobalamin deficiency/abnormalities of cobalamin metabolism: Nutritional, Malabsorption, absence of intrinsic factor, total/ partial gastrectomy.

* Folate deficiency/ abnormalities of folate metabolism.

* Therapy with antifolate drugs e.g., methotrexate.

* Independent of cobalamin/folate deficiency:

* Acute myeloid leukaemia, myelodysplasia.

* Therapy with drugs interfering with the synthesis of DNA (e.g., cytosine arabinoside, hydroxyurea, 6-mercaptopurine).

* Orotic aciduria (responds to uridine).

Other options:

The enzyme defects mentioned in the other options are not associated with megaloblastic anemia.

Option a: Dihydropyrimidine Dehydrogenase is responsible for the degradation of uracil and thiamine. Deficiency of the enzyme causes excessive urinary excretion of uracil and thymine.

Option b: Hereditary Xanthinuria is caused due to deficiency of xanthine oxidase, which causes all purine in the urine to occur in the form of hypoxanthine and xanthine.

Option c: Adenylosuccinate Lyase Deficiency is associated with profound psychomotor retardation, seizures, and other movement disorders.

Note: In Orotic Aciduria, peripheral blood smear shows Hypochromic megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text:
16. Pyruvate formed from glycolysis is converted into acetyl CoA. Which of the following co-factors are required for this reaction?

* Thiamine pyrophosphate

* Oleic acid 

* Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide

* Lipoic acid

* ATP
questions.solution:
Pyruvate is converted to acetyl CoA by the enzyme pyruvate dehydrogenase. The co-factors required for this reaction are thiamine pyrophosphate, nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide, and lipoic acid.

The given pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) complex is a multienzyme complex that is associated with the inner mitochondrial membrane. It catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA which enters the citric acid/Kreb’s cycle. It has 5 cofactors

Enzyme components of PDH complex                        Co-factors
Pyruvate dehydrogenase (E1) Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP)
Dihydrolipoyl transacetylase (E2)

Lipoic acid

Coenzyme A
Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase (E3)

Flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD)

Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+)


The other multienzyme complexes that catalyze oxidative decarboxylation reactions are 

* α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase in the citric acid cycle.

* Branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase is involved in the metabolism of leucine, isoleucine, and valine.

This can explain why a deficiency of thiamine causes reduced energy production.

questions.text:
17. Which of the following statements is not true for glycogen metabolism?

* Acetyl Co-A is a prime substrate to start gluconeogenesis.

* Glucose-6-phosphate inhibits glycogenolysis.

* Pompe disease is both a glycogen and lysosomal storage disorder.

* High insulin:glucagon ratio decreases glycogenesis.
questions.solution:
The false statements regarding glycogen metabolism are 1 and 4.

Acetyl coenzyme A is a common product of carbohydrate, protein, or fat catabolism. Statement 1 is false because it cannot give rise to a net synthesis of glucose (or glycogen) because of the irreversible nature of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, which converts pyruvate to acetyl CoA. It can only be used to produce ketone bodies.

Glycogen is a storage form of glucose and a number of enzymes and substrates tightly regulate its synthesis. Statement 4 is false because the increase in insulin and glucose-6-phosphate following a meal activates glycogen synthase, the rate-limiting enzyme in glycogenesis by dephosphorylation. Thus, high insulin:glucagon ratio increases glycogenesis.

An increase in glucagon or epinephrine causes the phosphorylation of enzymes, making glycogen synthase inactive. Glycogen breakdown occurs by glycogen phosphorylase which is activated by phosphorylation. Glycogen synthase and phosphorylase are reciprocally regulated.

Statement 2 is true. Active phosphorylase A, which phosphorylates and activates the glycogen phosphorylase enzyme, is allosterically inhibited by ATP and glucose-6-phosphate. Thus, glucose-6-phosphate leads to the inhibition of glycogenolysis.

Statement 3 is true. Impaired breakdown or synthesis of glycogen leads to a variety of disorders. Pompe's disease (type 2 glycogen storage disease) occurs due to α-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase) deficiency. It is the only glycogen storage disease that is a lysosomal storage disease and causes lysosomal glycogen accumulation in cardiac, skeletal, and smooth muscle cells. The clinical symptoms of Pompe disease are hypotonia (floppy infant), skeletal muscle weakness, hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and macroglossia.

questions.text:
18. Which of the following factors is not useful in distinguishing between the enzymes hexokinase and glucokinase?

Glucose-6-phosphate - G6P
questions.solution:
Hexokinase and glucokinase have common substrates and products, thus making them non-differentiable concerning this aspect.

Hexokinase is not an inducible enzyme. Hexokinase has a lower Vmax and a lower Km value than glucokinase. It is inhibited by glucose-6-phosphate.

Difference between Hexokinase and Glucokinase

Characteristics Hexokinase Glucokinase
Tissue distribution (Option C) Most tissues Liver and beta cells of the pancreas
Km (Option A) Low High

Vmax

 Low High
Inhibition by G6P (Option D) Yes No
Inducible  No Inducible 
Clinical significance Deficiency causes hemolytic anemia Less activity in diabetes mellitus
Biological significance Involved in maintaining intracellular glucose concentration  Involved in maintaining blood glucose concentration

questions.text: 19. A biochemist is studying the process of reconversion of lactate formed in the muscles and RBCs, back to glucose inside the liver and kidney cells. This conversion cycle is called as _________
questions.solution:
The process of reconversion of lactate formed in the muscles and RBCs, back to glucose inside the liver is called Cori's cycle. It links gluconeogenesis and anaerobic glycolysis.

Lactic acid is a metabolic byproduct formed after anaerobic glycolysis in tissues such as the skeletal muscles and RBCs. The lactate so formed is transported into the liver and kidney. Here, it gets reconverted back into pyruvate which can be converted to glucose. This entire process is called Cori’s cycle or the glucose–lactate cycle.

Significance: The cycle's importance is based on the prevention of lactic acidosis in the muscle under anaerobic conditions. However, normally before this happens the lactic acid is moved out of the muscles and into the liver.

Other options

Option A- Cahill cycle is also called the glucose–alanine cycle. In the fasting state, there is a significant output of alanine from skeletal muscle obtained from glycolysis of muscle glycogen. Alanine is derived from the transamination of pyruvate obtained from glycolysis. Alanine is then exported to the liver where it undergoes transamination again back to pyruvate and enters gluconeogenesis.

Option C- Kreb's cycle is the final common pathway for the oxidation of carbohydrates, lipids, and proteins because glucose, fatty acids, and most amino acids are metabolized to acetyl-CoA or intermediates of the cycle.

Option D- Urea cycle is also known as the Krebs–Henseleit cycle. It forms urea by detoxifying ammonia in the liver.

Pearl PM2309: Transport of ammonia in blood (Cahill and Cori cycle)

questions.text: 20. A biochemist is studying the process of reconversion of alanine formed in the muscles, back to glucose inside the liver. Which of the following is false regarding this cycle?
questions.solution:
The above cycle described is the glucose-alanine cycle or Cahill cycle and it is not active in fed state.

In the fasting state, muscle glycogen undergoes glycolysis. Pyruvate released during this glycolysis is transaminated to produce alanine. Alanine is then exported to the liver, where it undergoes transamination again back to pyruvate by alanine transaminase and enters gluconeogenesis to produce glucose. 

Also, this alanine serves as a transporter of ammonia. After reaching the liver the alanine is converted into pyruvate and glutamate by transaminase. The glutamate enters the urea cycle carrying the ammonia.

Pearl PM2309: Transport of ammonia in blood (Cahill and Cori cycle)
